H0.text: In WWII, who was the head of the Nazi party's security service. Himmler

H1.text: In WWII, who was the head of the Nazi party's security service. Göring

H2.text: In WWII, who was the head of the Nazi party's security service. Kaltenbrunner

H3.text: In WWII, who was the head of the Nazi party's security service. Heydrich

A4.text: From 1943 onwards, he was both Chief of the Kriminalpolizei (Criminal Police) and Minister of the Interior, which gave him oversight of all police and security forces (including the Gestapo).

A5.text: In 1931 he appointed Reinhard Heydrich chief of the new Ic Service (intelligence service), which was renamed the Sicherheitsdienst (SD: Security Service) in 1932.

A6.text: Hitler appointed Himmler chief of all German police outside Prussia.

A7.text: Himmler named his deputy and protégé Reinhard Heydrich chief of the Gestapo on 22 April 1934.

A8.text: Heydrich remained the RSHA chief until his assassination in 1942.

A9.text: In January 1943 Himmler delegated the office to SS-Obergruppenführer and General of Police Ernst Kaltenbrunner, who headed the RSHA until the end of the war in Europe.
